prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Types of Fiduciary Duties Owed—Subject-oriented fiduciary duty

para.paratext: The subject-oriented fiduciary duty is based on the nature of the information imparted. It requires that:
… unless authorized by the transferor, private information learned in confidence must not be used for the benefit of the recipient and must not be used against the interest of the transferor.
[The fiduciary relationship] depends upon continuation of the private nature of the information.
What triggers the duty of confidence is that at the moment he received private information the recipient knew or should have known that he was obligated to respect its confidentiality.[1]

In AF Industries Ltd. Liability Corp. v. Complete Innovations Inc.,[2] the Court of Appeal rejected the principal submission made by the appellant that the trial judge failed to give effect to her finding that the respondent breached a fiduciary duty owed by it to the appellant. The only breach of fiduciary duty specifically alleged in the statement of defence and repeated in the appellant's factum related to the respondent's alleged use of confidential information to the detriment of the appellant and “to extort monies from the Defendant”. The trial judge found that any alleged use of confidential information did not cause any damages to the appellant. This finding was open to the trial judge. This was not a case like McBride Metal Fabricating Corp. v. H & W Sales Co.,[3] where the trial judge found that had the plaintiff been aware of an apparent breach of fiduciary duty, it would have terminated the agreement. The only breach of fiduciary duty alleged here took place after the parties' agreement had been terminated. It was not open to the appellant to argue for the first time on appeal in oral argument that the breach of fiduciary duty occurred at an earlier time.[4]
R.J. Roberts, “Corporate Opportunity and Confidential Information” (1977), 28 C.P.R. (2d) 68 at pp. 75, 87–8.
AF Industries Ltd. Liability Corp. v. Complete Innovations Inc. 2014 CarswellOnt 749, 2014 ONCA 60.
McBride Metal Fabricating Corp. v. H & W Sales Co., 2002 CarswellOnt 1200, 59 O.R. (3d) 97.
